sen.j: 年貢（ねんぐ）は、日本史上の租税の一形態。
sen.e: Nengu is a form of taxation in the history of Japan.
Nengu is a form of taxation in the history of Japan.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Nengu is a Japanese historical terminology referring to a type of taxation.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 律令制における租が、平安初期～中期に律令制が崩壊・形骸化したことにともなって、年貢へと変質したが、貢租（こうそ）という別称に名残が残っている。
sen.e: The rice tax under Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) was altered to Nengu as the Ritsuryo system collapsed to be a dead letter in the early to middle of Heian period, and its relic is seen in another name, koso (annual tax).

The rice tax under Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) was altered to Nengu as the Ritsuryo system collapsed in the early to middle of Heian period, and its relic is known by another name, koso (annual tax).
sen.cmt: wordiness, grammar
sen.e: As the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on a set of codes) collapsed during the early to mid-Heian period, the system of taxation called so (tax) evolved into the nengu; the name nengu (annual tribute), however, kept something from its precedent, "koso" (the tribute-tax).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。貢租（こうそ） koso にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: その後、中世・近世を通じて、領主が百姓をはじめとする民衆に課する租税として存続した。
sen.e: Later through the medieval period and the early-modern times, it continued as the rice tax that feudal lords impose on their populace, such as peasants.
Later, through the medieval period and the early-modern times, it continued as the rice tax that feudal lords imposed on the peasants.
sen.cmt: wordiness, punctuation
sen.e: Throughout the medieval period and the early-modern times, the feudal lords imposed the nengu on the populace including the peasants.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 主に、米で納めるため、その米を年貢米（ねんぐまい）と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Because it was usually paid by rice, the rice was called nengumai (annual rice tax).
Because it was usually paid in rice, the rice was called nengumai (annual rice tax).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: As the nengu was mainly paid by rice, the rice used for the taxation purpose was called "nengumai" (the annual tribute rice).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。年貢米 nengumai にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: 7世紀末～8世紀初頭に始まった律令制における租税は、租庸調制と呼ばれ、人民一人ひとりを対象に課税・徴税する性格が強かった。
sen.e: The taxation under the Ritsuryo system that started in the late 7th century to the early 8th century was called Soyocho system (a tax system, corvee) was more characterized to be imposed on and collected from each of the people.

Taxation under the Ritsuryo system that started in the late 7th century and continued to the early 8th century was called the Soyocho system (a tax system, corvee) that was characterized to be imposed on and collected from each person.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The taxation system under the ritsuryo system, which was started during the late 7th century to the early 8th century, was called "the soyocho (tax paid by rice, labor, or textile) system", and it was imposed on and collected from each member of the community.
sen.cmt: 租庸調制はthe Soyocho system (a tax system, corvee)からthe soyocho (tax paid by rice, labor, or textile) systemへ変更しました。FBに従って修正しました。租庸調制 the soyocho (tax paid by rice, labor, or textile) system にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: こうした租税制度は、古代の戸籍制度・計帳の整備や国郡里（郷）制といった緻密な人民支配システムに大きく依存していた。
sen.e: Such a taxation system was greatly dependent on the precise people-governing system including maintenance of koseki (the household registers) system and the keicho (the yearly tax registers) in the ancient times and the Koku-gun-ri (-go) system (system of administrative divisions under the ritsuryo).

Such a taxation system was greatly dependent upon the precise people-governing system including the maintenance of the koseki (household registers) system and the keicho (yearly tax registers) in the ancient times and the Koku-gun-ri (-go) system (system of administrative divisions under the ritsuryo).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Such a taxation system greatly depended on systems which closely controlled the populace, such as the ancient systems used to maintain the koseki (household registers) and keicho (yearly tax registers), as well as the Koku-gun-ri (-go) system (an administrative system used to divide lands and regions).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。「古代の戸籍制度・計帳の整備や」の「整備や」部分が訳漏れに対応しました。国郡里（郷）制 the kokugunri / kokugungori を用語集の表記に合わせて the Koku-gun-ri (-go) system に修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、9世紀～10世紀ごろになると、百姓層の中で田地を開発・集積する富豪層が出現するようになった。
sen.e: In 9th to 10th centuries, however, the rich class appeared from the peasants, who developed and integrated the fields.
In the 9th to the 10th centuries, however, the rich class appeared from the peasants, who developed and integrated the fields.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: During the 9th and the 10th centuries, however, there appeared a wealthy class of peasants, who independently developed and integrated the cultivation fields.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: こうした富豪層は田堵と呼ばれ、開発・集積した田地の経営（営田）や出挙の実施などで富を蓄積し、一般の百姓を自らの経営下に組み込んでいった。
sen.e: Such a rich class was called Tato (cultivators), who accumulated their wealth by managing the fields developed and integrated (Eiden) and performing suiko (government loans, often seed rice, made to peasants in Japan from the 7th through 12th centuries), and set common peasants under their own management.

Such a rich class was called Tato (cultivators), who accumulated their wealth by managing the fields developed and integrated (Eiden) and performing suiko (government loans, often seed rice, made to peasants in Japan from the 7th through the 12th centuries), and set common peasants under their own management.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: This wealthy class of peasants, who were called "tato" (cultivators), accumulated wealth by developing and integrating fields (Eiden), as well as performing suiko (government loans, often seed rice, made to peasants in Japan from the 7th through the 12th centuries), and gained control over the ordinary peasants by involving them in their business.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。 “tato (cultivators),” を "tato" (cultivators), に修正しました。

sen.j: このような百姓内の階層分離が進んでいく中で、政府による律令制的支配は徐々に弛緩していき、戸籍・計帳の作成や班田などが実施されなくなっていった。
sen.e: With the class separation continuing among the peasants, the domination by the government based on the Ritsuryo system gradually relaxed, leading creation of the koseki and the keicho and handen (allotting farmland) not to be performed.

With class separation continuing among the peasants, domination by the government based upon the Ritsuryo system gradually relaxed, leading to the creation of the koseki and the keicho and handen (allotting farmland) not to be performed.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: As such a class division furthered among the population of peasants, the governmental control based upon the ritsuryo system gradually relaxed, and the bureaucratic procedures such as the household registers (koseki), the yearly tax registers (handen), and allotting of cultivation fields (handen) were no longer carried out.
sen.cmt: 支配はdominationではなく、controlと訳しました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: そうなると、人民一人ひとりを収取（課税・徴税）単位としていた人別支配はもはや不可能となり、政府や支配層にとって別の支配体制を構築する必要が生じていた。
sen.e: In such a circumstance, the personal domination by imposing and collecting taxes from each person was not possible, and there was a need of constructing another domination system for the government and dominating classes.

Under such circumstances, personal domination by imposing and collecting taxes from each person was not possible, and there was a need to construct another domination system for the government and the dominate classes.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Under such circumstances, controlling each member of the community by imposing and collecting taxes was no longer possible, and the government and the ruling class were becoming aware of the necessity for a new control system.
sen.cmt: 支配はdominationではなく、controlと訳しました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: まず、公田を支配していた国衙が、当時台頭しつつあった田堵と連携して、土地を収取単位とする支配体制を築き始めた。
sen.e: First, kokuga (provincial government office compounds) that governed public fields started to construct a dominating system by imposing and collecting taxes in units of lands, in cooperation with the tato rising at the time.

First, kokuga (provincial government office compounds) that governed public fields started to construct a dominate system by imposing and collecting taxes based on land units, in cooperation with the tato that was rising at the time.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: First, the kokuga (provincial government office) that governed public fields, together with the "tato" who were rapidly gaining power, established a control system of imposing and collecting taxes based on land units.
sen.cmt: 国衙の説明文はprovincial government office compoundsではなく、provincial government officeとしました。支配はdominationではなく、controlと訳しました。FBに従って修正しました。”tato” のダブルクォーテーションを全角から半角に修正しました。

sen.j: 国衙は、国内の公田を名田に再編成し、名田経営を田堵へ請け負わせ始めた。
sen.e: The tato rearranged the public fields in the country into myoden (rice field lots in charge of a nominal holder) and started contracting the management of the myoden out with the tato.
The tato rearranged the public fields in the country into myoden (rice field lots in charge of a nominal holder) and started contracting the management of the myoden out with the tato.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The kokuga reorganized the public fields into myoden (rice field lots in charge of a nominal holder), and placed the tato in charge of managing the myoden.
sen.cmt: 国衙の説明文はprovincial government office compoundsではなく、provincial government officeとしました。FBに従って修正しました。「国衙は」前の文章でthe kokuga の説明文が出ているため、主語を統一しました。The regional offices →The kokuga

sen.j: 名田経営を請け負った田堵は、従前の田租や調・庸・雑徭・正税出挙に相当する分量を国衙へ納入した。
sen.e: The tato that undertook the management of the myoden paid an amount corresponding to the former taso, cho (tributes), yo (tax in kind), zoyo (irregular corvee), and public suiko to the kokuga.
sen.cmt: 正税出挙＝公出挙(国が行う出挙)なのでpublic suikoの訳を使用しました。
sen.e: The tato that undertook the management of the myoden paid an amount corresponding to the former taso, cho (tributes), yo (tax in kind), zoyo (irregular corvee), and public suiko to the kokuga.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The tato, who were given the managerial position over the myoden, paid in return an amount which corresponded to the taxes formerly paid by rice, textiles, tributes, labor, or the shozei-suiko (interest for the loan of cereal seeds) to the regional offices.
sen.cmt: 田租や調・庸・雑徭・正税出挙はrice, textiles, tributes, labor, or the shozei-suiko (interest for the loan of cereal seeds)と訳しました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: こうした租税請負の形態を負名（ふみょう）という。
sen.e: Such a system of contracting the rice tax is called Fumyo (tiller of the public rice field).
Such a system of contracting the rice tax is called Fumyo (tiller of the public rice field).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Such a system of managing the tax was called fumyo (the management of public rice fields).
sen.cmt: 負名は(tiller of the public rice field)から(the management of public rice fields)へ変更しました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 上記のうち、主として田租や正税出挙に由来するものを官物（かんもつ）といい、主として調・庸・雑徭に由来するものを雑役（ぞうやく）といった。
sen.e: Among the above, those mainly derived from the public suiko were called kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), and those mainly derived from the so, yo, and zoyo were called zoyaku.
Among the above, those mainly derived from the public suiko were called kanmotsu (tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), and those mainly derived from the so, yo, and zoyo were called zoyaku.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Among the taxes mentioned above, those that corresponded to tax paid by rice and the shozei-suiko were called kanmotsu (the tribute goods paid as taxes or tithes), and those that corresponded to tax paid by textiles, tributes, labor were called zoyaku (the miscellaneous duties).
sen.cmt: 雑役の説明文(the miscellaneous duties)を追記しました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: そして、官物にあたるものが年貢となっていくのである。
sen.e: Those corresponding to the kanmotsu later became the nengu.
Those corresponding to kanmotsu later became nengu.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Those that were called kanmotsu later became nengu.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 以上のような名田を中心とする収取体制（これを名体制または名田制という）は、11世紀～12世紀以降、一円化して領域制を高めつつあった荘園にも導入された。
sen.e: The imposing and collecting system based on the myoden (referred to as fumyo system or myoden system) as described above was also introduced to shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that was expanding in wider areas after eleventh to twelfth centuries.
sen.cmt: 名体制は、負名体制の誤りと思われます。[http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E8%B2%A0%E5%90%8D]「一円化して領域制を高める」とは、「広域に広がる」という意味と解釈しました。
sen.e: The imposing and collecting system based on the myoden (referred to as the umyo or myoden system) described above was also introduced to shoen (manor in medieval Japan) that was expanding in wider areas after eleventh to twelfth centuries.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The taxation system centered on the myoden (known as the myotai or myoden system) was also introduced to shoen (manors in medieval Japan) that were expanding their areas of control since the eleventh and twelfth centuries.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。「名体制」を fumyo (system) から myotai (system) に修正しました。

sen.j: 荘園内の田地は名田へ再編成され、田堵らが名田経営と領主への貢納を請け負った。
sen.e: Fields in the shoen were integrated into myoden, and the tato and others undertook the management of the myoden and the payment of the taxes to the feudal lord.
Fields in the shoen were integrated into myoden, and the tato and others undertook the management of the myoden and the payment of taxes to the feudal lord.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The cultivation fields in the shoen were integrated into the myoden, and the tato undertook the management of the myoden and the payment of taxes to the manor owners.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 領主への貢納のうち、国衙領でいう官物にあたるもの（田地からの収穫米）が年貢と呼ばれるようになった。
sen.e: Among the taxes paid to the feudal lord, what corresponds to the kanmotsu in Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) (rice crops from the rice field) started to be called nengu.
Among taxes paid to the feudal lord, what corresponds to the kanmotsu in Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government office) (rice crops from the rice field) started to be called nengu.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Among taxes paid to the feudal lord, what corresponded to the kanmotsu (rice harvested from the landlords' cultivation fields) in Kokugaryo (territories governed by provincial government offices) came to be called "nengu".
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。the landlords’ cultivation fields のアポストロフィを全角から半角に修正しました。governmentoffices を government offices に修正しました。年貢 nengu にダブルクォーテーションを追記しました。

sen.j: こうして成立した年貢は、その後の中世・近世を通じて、支配層の主要な財源として位置づけられ、被支配層にとっては年貢を負担する義務が課され続けたのである。
sen.e: Through the medieval period and the early-modern times later, the nengu thus established was positioned as the main financial resource, and the dominated class remained obliged to pay the nengu.
Through the medieval period and early-modern times, the nengu later established was positioned as the main financial resource, and the dominate class remained obliged to pay the nengu.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: Through the medieval period and early-modern times, the nengu was the principal financial resource for the ruling class, which the ordinary population continued to bear its burden.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 鎌倉時代になると、商品経済が発展していき、貨幣流通が増加し、中には銭貨で年貢を納入する代銭納が行われるケースも出てきた。
sen.e: In Kamakura period, commodity economy grew, money circulation increased, and there were some cases of daisenno where the nengu was paid in coins.
In the Kamakura period, the commodity economy grew, money circulation increased, and there were some cases of daisenno where the nengu was paid in coins.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: As the commercial economy developed during the Kamakura period, the circulation of money increased, and in some cases, the nengu was paid by coins.
sen.cmt: 商品経済はthe commercial economyと訳しました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: ただし、そうしたケースは非常にまれで、物納された年貢を荘官や地頭が換金することの方が多かった。
sen.e: However, such cases were very few, and, in most cases, shokan (an officer governing shoen) or jito (manager and lord of shoen) exchanged the paid nengu with money.
However, such cases were very few, and, in most cases, shokan (an officer governing shoen) or jito (manager and lord of shoen) exchanged the paid nengu for money.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, such cases were very rare, and in most cases, shokan (the administrative officer of shoen) or jito (the manager of shoen) exchanged the rice brought in as the nengu for money.
sen.cmt: shokan (an officer governing shoen)からshokan (the administrative officer of shoen)へ変更。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 室町時代に入ると、貨幣経済が一層進展し、年貢の銭納または代銭納（銭貨による年貢納入）が畿内を中心に広く普及するようになった。
sen.e: In Muromachi period, the money circulation developed further, and senno, or daisenno, of the nengu (payment of nengu in coins) became widely spread mainly in Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto).
sen.cmt: 銭納及び代銭納は同義と思われますので、並列記載しました。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, money circulation developed further, and senno, or daisenno, of the nengu (payment of nengu in coins) became widely spread, mainly in the Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto).
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the monetary economy developed further, and the payment of the nengu by coins became widely spread mainly in the Kinai region (the five capital provinces surrounding the ancient capitals of Nara and Kyoto).
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 安土桃山時代に実施された太閤検地により、一つの土地に対する重層的な支配・権利関係がほぼ全て解消された。
sen.e: Thanks to Taiko-kenchi (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) executed in Azuchi-Momoyama period, multi-layered domination and rights over a piece of land were almost entirely eliminated.
Thanks to Taiko-kenchi (the land survey by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) executed in Azuchi-Momoyama period, multi-layered domination and rights over a piece of land were almost entirely eliminated.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: As a result of the Taiko kenchi (the nationwide land survey done by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI) carried out in the Azuchi-Momoyama period, the complicated pattern of control and rights over the land were almost entirely dissolved.
sen.cmt: 太閤検地は(the nationwide land survey done by Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI)と訳しました。FBに従って修正しました。太閤検地 Taiko-kenchi のハイフンを削除しました。

sen.j: 一つの土地の耕作者がその土地の唯一の権利者となり、土地の生産力は米の見込生産量である石高で計られることとなった。
sen.e: A farmer of the land became the only person entitled to own the land, and it was determined to measure the productivity of the land by kokudaka, an estimated amount of rice to be produced in the land.
Farmers became the only people entitled to own land, and it was determined to measure land productivity by kokudaka, an estimated amount of rice to be produced from the land.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The cultivator of the land was considered the only person who was entitled to own the land, and the productivity of the land was measured by kokudaka, an estimated amount of rice to be produced from the land.
sen.cmt: 耕作者はFarmerではなくcultivatorとしました。FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 年貢については、石高を村落全体で集計した村高（むらだか）に応じた額が、村の年貢量とされ、年貢納入は村落が一括納入の義務を負う村請（むらうけ）の形態が採用された。
sen.e: Murauke system (village-wide, collective responsibility for tax payment) was employed to collect the nengu, where an amount corresponding to muradaka, the total kokudaka of the whole village, is determined to be the amount of the nengu from the village, and the village is obliged to pay the whole muradaka at a time.

The murauke system (village-wide, collective responsibility for tax payment) was employed to collect the nengu, where an amount corresponding to muradaka, the total kokudaka of the whole village, determined to be the amount of the nengu from the village, and the village is obliged to pay the whole muradaka at one time.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The murauke system (a village's collective responsibility for tax payment) was established in order to collect the nengu from the village as a collective unit, in which an amount of nengu was determined from the total kokudaka of the entire village.
sen.cmt: 村請（むらうけ）の形態はThe murauke system (a village’s collective responsibility for tax payment) としました。a village’s collective responsibility のアポストロフィを全角から半角に修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代になっても、太閤検地による村落支配体制はほぼそのまま継承され、村請制がとられた。
sen.e: The system of dominating villages based on the Taiko-kenchi remained almost as it was even in Edo period, where the murauke system was employed.
The system of dominate villages based on the Taiko-kenchi remained almost as they were, even in the Edo period, when the murauke system was employed.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: The control system of villages based on the Taiko kenchi and the murauke system was continued throughout the Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。太閤検地 Taiko-kenchi のハイフンを削除しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代前期の年貢徴収は、田を視察してその年の収穫量を見込んで毎年ごとに年貢率を決定する検見法（けみ-）を採用していた。
sen.e: In the early Edo period, kemi-ho (annual crop inspections) of inspecting the rice fields to estimate an amount of the crops in the year, thereby determining the nengu rate every year.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the early Edo period, kemi-ho (annual crop inspections) inspecting rice fields to estimate the amount of the crop yield in the year, and thereby determining the nengu rate every year.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In the early Edo period, kemi-ho (annual crop inspections), with which the amount of the crop yield during that year was estimated and the rate of nengu to be paid each year was determined, was carried out.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、年によって収入が大きく変動するリスクを負っていたことから、江戸中期ごろになると、豊作・不作にかかわらず一定の年貢率による定免法（じょうめん-）がとられるようになった。
sen.e: However, due to a risk that the revenue may greatly vary year by year, jomen-ho that uses a fixed nengu rate no matter rich harvest or poor harvest was employed around mid Edo period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, due to the element of risk whereby the revenue may vary greatly year by year, jomen-ho that uses a fixed nengu rate whether the harvest was a rich or poor one, was employed around mid Edo period.
sen.cmt: revised for clarity
sen.e: However, due to the risk whereby the revenue can vary greatly year by year, jomen-ho, which employed a fixed nengu rate regardless of the amount of the harvest, was employed during the mid-Edo period.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: だが、例外も存在した。
sen.e: However, there was an exception.
However, there was an exception.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: However, there was an exception.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: 米が取れない地域の一部では商品作物等の売却代金をもって他所から米を購入して納税用の年貢に充てるという買納制が例外的に認められていた。
sen.e: In a part of areas where rice cannot be produced, baino-sei system of purchasing rice from other areas with money earned by selling commercial crops to pay the nengu was permitted as an exception.
sen.cmt: 「買納制」の読みが確認できませんでしたので「ばいのうせい」として訳しました。
sen.e: In some of areas where rice cannot be produced, the baino-sei system of purchasing rice from other areas with money earned by selling commercial crops to pay the nengu was permitted as an exception.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: For the areas where rice cannot be produced, the baino-sei system, in which rice to be paid as nengu was purchased with money earned by selling other kinds of crops, was employed as an exception.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: だが、江戸時代中期以後商品作物の生産が広まってくると都市周辺部の農村など本来は米の生産が可能な地域においてもなし崩しに買納制が行われていき、江戸幕府さえもが事実上の黙認政策を採らざるを得なくなった。
sen.e: However, as the production of the commercial crops gained wider ground after mid Edo period, the baino-sei started little by little even in farming villages surrounding urban areas where rice can be produced, and even the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) had no other way but virtually to take a acquiescence policy.

However, as the production of commercial crops gained wider ground after the mid Edo period, baino-sei started little by little even in farming villages that surrounded urban areas where rice can be produced, and even the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) had no other way, but virtually to take an acquiescence policy.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, as the production of commercial crops became widely spread during the mid-Edo period, baino-sei was carried out even in suburban villages where rice can be produced, to which the Edo bakufu virtually took an acquiescence policy.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 1873年（明治6年）の地租改正により年貢は廃止されることとなる。
sen.e: The nengu was abolished by the land-tax reform in 1873.
The nengu was abolished by the land-tax reform in 1873.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The nengu was abolished by the land-tax reform in 1873.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: しかし、その後も小作料を年貢と呼ぶ慣習が残った。
sen.e: However, there still remained a custom of calling farm rent the nengu.
However, the custom of calling farm rent nengu still remained.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: However, the custom of calling the farm rent as the nengu continued to survive.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。

sen.j: 日本語では、物事をあきらめなくてはならない時のことを「年貢の納め時」という。
sen.e: In Japanese, when one has to give up something, they say "it is time to pay the nengu."
In Japanese, when one has to give up something, he says "it is time to pay the nengu."
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: In Japanese, there is an expression "it is time to pay the nengu" when one has to give up something.
sen.cmt: FBに従って修正しました。“it is time to pay the nengu” ダブルクォーテーションを全角から半角に修正しました。

sen.j: 何とかして年貢納入を回避しようと、庶民が必死に努力していたことを物語っている。
sen.e: It explains that common people tried very hard to avoid paying the nengu by all means.
This shows that common people tried very hard to avoid paying the nengu.
sen.cmt: grammar
sen.e: This shows that common people tried very hard to avoid paying the nengu.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
